clinical_study.brief_title: Identify the Frequency of Enteric Zoster Through Salivary Varicella-Zoster Virus(VZV) DNA Polymerase Chain Reaction(PCR)
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Study to Identify the Frequency of Enteric Zoster Through Salivary VZV DNA PCR in Nonspecific Abdominal Pain Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to identify the frequency of enteric zoster using salivary VZV DNA PCR in acute abdominal pain patients who visit the emergency room (ER). For this purpose, the investigators enrolled patients who visit Asan Medical center ER due to this complaint.

detailed_description.textblock:
On previous studies, investigators found that salivary VZV DNA PCR was a biomarker for acute VZV infection regardless of typical zoster skin lesions. In the case of the enteric zoster, VZV establishes latency in neurons of the enteric nervous system that do not innervate skin. Therefore, VZV reactivation in these neurons doesn's show typical zoster skin rash, causes diverse gastrointestinal symptoms. Our purpose is to investigate the usefulness of salivary VZV DNA PCR in patients with enteric zoster and the frequency of enteric zoster in patients with abdominal pain who visit the ER.
About 260 patients aged ≥18, and <80 years with acute abdominal pain (NRS ≥ 6 'AND' unresponsive to gastrointestinal motility drug, antacid) will be enrolled.
1. Sample collection: Saliva sample (at least 1 mL) is collected with a special kit once patients visit the ER.
2. Sample analysis: DNA is extracted and VZV DNA is quantified with a VZV-specific real-time PCR kit, using a LightCycler 480 System.

primary_outcome.measure: Frequency of enteric zoster in undiagnosed group
primary_outcome.description: The frequency of enteric zoster in patients with nonspecific abdominal pain who are undiagnosed by radiologic images

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged ≥18, and <80 years
- ER-visit patients with acute abdominal pain
- NRS ≥ 6
- Unresponsive to gastrointestinal motility drug, antacid
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unwilling or unable to give informed consent
- Patients who take antiviral agents (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir, ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet...)
- Patients complaining abdominal pain with NRS ≤ 5 or improved symptom by gastrointestinal motility drug, antacid
